title: Viewing History
subtitle: Time Travel Through Your Commits
description:
# Exploring Your Project History

One of Git's superpowers is the ability to see everything that happened in your project. Who changed what? When? Why?

## The `git log` Command

The `git log` command shows you the commit history:

```bash
git log
```

This displays:
- Commit ID (a unique hash like `a3f2c1d...`)
- Author name and email
- Date and time
- Commit message

### Useful `git log` Options

```bash
# Compact one-line view
git log --oneline

# Show last 5 commits
git log -5

# Show commits with file changes
git log --stat

# Visual graph of branches
git log --graph --oneline
```

## The `git diff` Command

Want to see exactly what changed? Use `git diff`:

```bash
# See unstaged changes
git diff

# See staged changes
git diff --staged

# Compare two commits
git diff commit1 commit2
```

### Reading Diff Output

```diff
- This line was removed (red)
+ This line was added (green)
  This line stayed the same
```

## Example Workflow

```bash
# Make some changes to a file
echo "Hello Git!" > greeting.txt

# See what changed (before staging)
git diff

# Stage the changes
git add greeting.txt

# See staged changes
git diff --staged

# Commit
git commit -m "Add greeting file"

# View commit history
git log --oneline
```
